message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest knee osteoarthritis, which is characterized by marginal sclerosis on imaging studies. Association with HLA-DR4 is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis of the hands, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of pain and tenderness along the medial joint line are most consistent with osteoarthritis. Among the choices, marginal sclerosis is a radiographic finding commonly seen in osteoarthritis characterized by an increased density at the joint margins. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes with osteoarthritis of the hands, and joint pannus with rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest osteoarthritis, which is commonly seen in older individuals. Marginal sclerosis, or thickening of the bony areas surrounding the joint, is a common finding in osteoarthritis. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis of the fingers, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and tenderness along the medial joint line suggest osteoarthritis. Among the options, only marginal sclerosis is a typical radiographic finding in osteoarthritis. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are associated with osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints, and joint pannus is a feature of rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with left knee pain and tenderness along the medial joint line, which suggests medial compartment osteoarthritis. Marginal sclerosis is a radiographic finding commonly seen in osteoarthritis. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis but typically involve the distal interphalangeal joints, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has tenderness along the medial joint line suggesting osteoarthritis, which is often characterized by marginal sclerosis on imaging. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis of the hands, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest osteoarthritis, which is commonly associated with marginal sclerosis on radiography. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis but not specific to the knee, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with knee pain, especially in the afternoon after being active, and tenderness along the medial joint line. These are classic symptoms of osteoarthritis, which is characterized by marginal sclerosis. The other options are associated with other types of arthritis or have different clinical presentations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with left knee pain that started after a fall, and has tenderness along the medial joint line. This is indicative of osteoarthritis, which is associated with marginal sclerosis on X-ray. HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis of the hands, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest osteoarthritis of the knee, and among the options, marginal sclerosis is commonly seen in osteoarthritis. Association with HLA-DR4 is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, Heberden nodes are seen in osteoarthritis of the hands, and joint pannus is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.
